title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [5? april 1873]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [5? April 1873]
text: My dear waltWalt i received your letter to day waltWalt its a great consolation to get your letters nearly all the comfort i have) as i have no one to talk tooto about any of my own i get letters from helen price real good ones she is more like our own folks than any one else except you) O waltWalt i doodo want you to get well so much) well walterWalter dear you remember i told you saturdaySaturday i would give you an account of our affairs) well waltWalt i should never have made any complaint if you hadenthadn't have wrote to me you should certainly get a place for you and eddEdd and me i hope you may succeed walterWalter i have not been very happy here but i thought you had trouble enoughfenough without hearing mine they think Lou is in the family way and therefore she has to be kept up stairs in my room and waited upon by her aunt her vitualsvictuals took up and the aunt is very faithful and the doctor comes one day twice and after eating she comes down stairs and she says georgeGeorge wants her aunt to stay they pay her wages) i have been down in the kichenkitchen ever since i got up this morning till i come up to writwrite this letter i have had very little good of my room this winter as they have all lived and had all their company up here sometimes it was very disagreabledisagreeable to me but i have lived through all the annoyances some real and some immaginaryimaginary but sometimes i felt in hopes but walterWalter dear i wontwon't say any more but i pray and hope you may get well and we can have a home of our own if itsit's ever so plain) you pay 20 dollars here every month i think we could live on 40 that would be for provitionsprovisions and if i should get sick i should much prefer being with you walterWalter than here as i have many friends that would only be too glad to come and care for me i know i cantcan't work like i once could but i doodo more here than i feel able to i have been pretty well until lately i have not had much appetite but i will feel better i gessguess i have got nerviousnervous dontdon't write any thing walterWalter to make them think i complained maybe i had not ought to but little things cuts sometimes the aunt is englishEnglish and Lou is englishEnglish and i am very sensitive and georgeGeorge is absorbed in his businessgeorgeGeorge has commenced his house the cellar is being dug he builds quite a large house is to be done about augustAugust or if i could or you could get a place by that time i dontdon't think walterWalter it would cost you more to live than it does now good bie walterWalter dear Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [5? April 1873]
